boxed-text.p: Intranasal SARS-CoV-2 saRNA vaccination induces systemic and mucosal immunity in mice, and prevents morbidity and blocks viral transmission in hamsters.

caption.title: Design of saRNA-NLC SARS-CoV-2 vaccine AAHI-SC2.
caption.p: (A) saRNA SARS-CoV-2 construct diagram. (B) NLC-RNA complex diagram.

caption.title: Systemic immunogenicity of intranasally administered SARS-CoV-2 saRNA-NLC vaccine.
caption.p: Systemic immunogenicity was assessed 3 weeks post-prime or post-boost in C57BL/6J mice immunized with AAHI-SC2 i.m. at 10 µg or i.n. at 1, 5, or 10 µg or a vector control (SEAP) i.n. at 10 µg at day 0 and day 21. n = 8 mice per group, evenly split male-female. (A) Serum SARS-CoV-2 spike-specific IgG responses measured post-prime and post-boost. LOD = limit of detection. (B) Serum SARS-CoV-2 spike Wuhan pseudovirus neutralizing titers measured post-prime and post-boost. (A-B) Data were log transformed and analyzed by a mixed-effects model with Tukey’s multiple comparisons test. (C) Serum spike-specific IgG1 and IgG2a responses measured post-boost. (D) Induction of bone marrow-resident spike-specific IgG-secreting ASCs as measured by ELISpot 3 weeks post-boost. (E-G) SARS-CoV-2 spike-responsive secretion of IFNγ, IL-5, or IL-17a by splenocytes post-boost as measured by ELISpot in mice dosed with 10 µg of saRNA. All bars on graphs show geometric mean ± geometric SD. (H-I) Splenic spike-responsive polyfunctional T cells (IFNγ+, IL-2+, and TNFα+ CD4+ or CD8+ T cells) post-boost as measured by intracellular cytokine staining and flow cytometry. Horizontal lines show mean ± SD. See Figure S1 for flow cytometry gating strategies. (D-I) Data were analyzed by one-way ANOVA with Tukey’s multiple comparisons test. *p < 0.05 and ****p < 0.0001.

caption.title: Mucosal T cell populations following intranasal vaccination with SARS-CoV-2 saRNA-NLC candidate.
caption.p: T cell populations in the lungs were assessed 3 weeks post-prime and post-boost in C57BL/6J mice immunized with 10 µg of AAHI-SC2 either i.m. or i.n. n = 8 mice per group, evenly split male-female. Vector control-dosed mice were also included in the experiment and are shown in Figure 4. See Figure S3 for sample flow cytometry gating strategies. (A-B) CD69+ lung-resident memory (A) CD8+ and (B) CD103+ CD8+ T cells. (C) CD40L+ (CD154+)-expressing CD4+ T cells. Percentage of cells in total live lung cells per mouse indicated by dots with horizontal line at median. Data were analyzed by two-way ANOVA with Sidak’s multiple comparisons test. **p < 0.01 and ****p < 0.0001.

caption.title: Mucosal SARS-CoV-2 spike polyfunctionally reactive T cell populations following immunization with the intranasal or intramuscular SARS-CoV-2 saRNA-NLC vaccine.
caption.p: T cell populations in the lungs were stimulated with SARS-CoV-2 spike peptides for 6 hours and stained for T cell markers and cytokine expression 3 weeks post-boost in C57BL/6J mice immunized with 1, 5, or 10 µg of the i.n. saRNA-NLC vaccine, relative to 10 µg of the i.m. vaccine or an i.n. vector control (SEAP) saRNA-NLC. n = 8 mice for all dosing groups. Percentages of polyfunctional cells (expressing IFNγ, IL-2, and TNFα) were then measured by flow cytometry. (A-B) Polyfunctional CD69+ lung-resident memory (A) CD8+ and (B) CD103+ CD8+ T cells. (C) Polyfunctional CD40L-expressing (CD154+) CD4+ T cells. (D-E) Polyfunctional CCR4-expressing (CD194+) lung-homing (D) CD4+ and (E) CD8+ T cells. Dots represent values measured from individual mice. Horizontal lines indicate data median. Significance was determined by one-way ANOVA with Tukey’s multiple comparisons test: *p < 0.05, **p < 0.01, and *** p < 0.001.

caption.title: Systemic and mucosal immune responses following boost immunization with the intranasal or intramuscular SARS-CoV-2 saRNA-NLC vaccines.
caption.p: 10-week-old C57BL/6J mice were injected i.m. with a 10-µg prime dose (N:P of 15) and then boosted with a 5-µg dose of either the i.n. or i.m. saRNA-NLC vaccine 7 weeks later. n = female 5 mice per group. (A) SARS-CoV-2 spike-specific IgG titers as measured by ELISA 3 weeks post-boost. Horizontal lines show median. (B) Serum SARS-CoV-2 pseudovirus neutralizing titers 3 weeks post-boost. Horizontal lines show median. (C-D) Spleen polyfunctional (D) CD4+ and (E) CD8+ T cell responses. (E) Polyfunctional CD40L-expressing (CD154+) CD4+ T cells. (F) Polyfunctional lung-resident memory CD69+ CD8+ T cell responses. Statistics evaluated as unpaired two-sided homoscedastic t tests, *p < 0.05. Bars on graphs show mean with SD.

caption.title: Protection from SARS-CoV-2 infection-induced morbidity, viral load, and lung damage in vaccinated hamsters.
caption.p: (A) Study design for experiment in vaccinated and sham-vaccinated co-housed hamsters. Acclimated co-housed hamster pairs were separated on day 0. One animal in each pair was vaccinated i.n. or i.m. or was sham-vaccinated. The other animal in each pair was left untouched (naive, see Figure 7). Sham-vaccinated and vaccinated animals were re-paired with their naive cagemates on day 1. Blood was collected from all animals on day 21. Animals were separated again on day 28, and sham-vaccinated and vaccinated animals were boosted either i.n. or i.m. Animals were re-paired with their naive cagemates on day 29, and blood was collected on day 33. (B-C) Vaccine antibody responses in sham-vaccinated (open black circles), i.n.-prime/i.n.-boost vaccinated (blue diamonds), i.m.-prime/i.m.-boost vaccinated (yellow squares), or i.m.-prime/i.n.-boost vaccinated (green triangles) animals. n = 5-6/group. Mean fluorescence intensity (MFI) of serum anti-spike IgG on day 21 (B) and day 33 (C). Data were log-transformed and assessed by two-way ANOVA with Tukey’s multiple comparison test. Horizontal lines show geometric mean. (D-H) Experimental infection in sham-vaccinated and vaccinated hamsters. Vaccinated and sham-vaccinated hamsters were separated from their naive cagemates on day 37 (see panel A). Two sham-vaccinated hamsters were left uninfected (grey triangles, sham-vaccinated-uninfected), and all remaining sham-vaccinated and vaccinated animals were experimentally infected with SARS-CoV-2 via the intranasal route. (D) Body weight of vaccinated-infected, sham-vaccinated-infected, and sham-vaccinated-uninfected hamsters. Body weight line plots show group weight mean and SEM. Body weight data was analyzed on area under the curve measures, assessed statistically by one-way ANOVA with Tukey’s multiple comparison test. (E-F) Total N RNA (E) and subgenomic N RNA (F) copy number in nasal swipes from vaccinated-infected and sham-vaccinated-infected hamsters. Viral RNA measures were log-transformed and shown as mean and SEM. Area under the curve measures were assessed with one-way ANOVA with Tukey’s multiple comparison test. (G) Anti-N IgG in serum of vaccinated-infected and sham-vaccinated-infected animals is shown as MFI after log-transformation. Data statistically analyzed using one-way ANOVA with Dunnett’s multiple comparisons test. (H) Lung pathology scores were calculated for sham-vaccinated-infected and vaccinated-infected animals. Horizontal lines and error bars represent mean and SD, respectively. See Figure S6 for representative histopathology images. * p < 0.05, ** p < 0.01, *** p < 0.001, **** p < 0.0001.

caption.title: Vaccination prevents transmission of SARS-CoV-2 to naive hamster cagemates.
caption.p: (A) Study design for transmission experiment in naive cagemates. Vaccinated and sham-vaccinated hamsters were separated from their naive cagemates on day -2 (day 37 in Figure 6A) and then experimentally infected with SARS-CoV-2. On day 0 (day 39 in Figure 6A), the naive animals were re-paired with their vaccinated-infected or sham-vaccinated-infected cagemates. On day 1 (day 40 in Figure 6A), the animals were separated and the naive cagemates were monitored for SARS-CoV-2 infection and infection-induced morbidity. (B) Body weight of the naive cagemates that were re-paired for 24 hours with vaccinated-infected or sham-vaccinated-infected hamsters. Body weight line plots show group weight mean and SEM. Body weight data was analyzed on area under the curve measures, assessed statistically by one-way ANOVA with Tukey’s multiple comparison test. (C-D) Total N RNA (C) and subgenomic N RNA (D) copy number in nasal swipes from naive cagemates that were re-paired for 24 hours with vaccinated-infected and sham-vaccinated-infected hamsters. Viral RNA copy numbers were log-transformed, and area under the curve measures are shown as mean and SEM. Data were assessed with one-way ANOVA with Tukey’s multiple comparison test. (E) Anti-N IgG in serum of naive cagemates that were re-paired for 24 hours with vaccinated-infected and sham-vaccinated-infected groups. Antibody levels are reported as mean fluorescence intensity (MFI) following log-transformation. Data statistically analyzed using one-way ANOVA with Dunnett’s multiple comparisons test. (F) Lung pathology scores were calculated for naive cagemates that were re-paired for 24 hours with sham-vaccinated-infected and vaccinated-infected animals. Horizontal lines and error bars represent mean and SD, respectively. See Figure S6 for representative histopathology images. * p < 0.05, **** p < 0.0001.
